description: Iraq invaded Kuwait, triggering fears of oil supply disruption in the Middle East. Led to immediate price surge.
Operation Desert Storm launched. Initial price spike followed by decline as fears of prolonged disruption eased.
Financial crisis began in Thailand and spread across Asia, reducing oil demand significantly.
OPEC increased production despite weak Asian demand, leading to oil price collapse to below $10/barrel.
Terrorist attacks on US led to economic uncertainty and temporary oil market disruption.
National strike in Venezuela disrupted oil production in the world's fifth-largest oil exporter.
US-led invasion of Iraq. Initial price spike due to supply concerns, followed by volatility.
Brent crude reached record high of $147/barrel driven by demand growth and speculation before financial crisis.
Lehman Brothers collapse triggered global financial crisis, causing dramatic oil demand destruction and price collapse.
Political uprisings across Middle East and North Africa disrupted oil production, particularly in Libya.
Japan nuclear disaster increased global oil demand as Japan shifted from nuclear to fossil fuels.
OPEC decided not to cut production despite falling prices, triggering oil price collapse from $100+ to below $30.
OPEC agreed to first production cut in 8 years, joined by Russia (OPEC+), stabilizing oil markets.
US reimposed sanctions on Iran, removing ~1 million barrels/day from market.
COVID-19 lockdowns destroyed demand while Saudi Arabia and Russia engaged in price war. Prices briefly went negative.
OPEC+ agreed to largest production cut in history (9.7 million bpd) in response to pandemic demand collapse.
Russia's invasion of Ukraine and subsequent Western sanctions created major supply concerns and price surge.
